It's here... now I want car using same technology, but first we have to build roads with permanent magnets :/
It's just a nice publicity stunt. Don't expect to own one of those any time soon. Without room temperature superconductors this kind of levitation is not an economical solution.

It's 2015, we have **a** hoverboard now but **the** hoverboard.

It was a letdown when they show in "

<iframe width="480" height="270" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/q_BYvUlDviM?feature=oembed" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen="true"></iframe>
" that it's just a track strategically placed and covered up so that it looks like a normal skating rink.
Yes it doesn't touch the ground, it has that freedom. It doesn't have the freedom that the first video implies or at least it doesn't deny it.

If what the board is doing is explained in this video:

<iframe width="480" height="270" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/zPqEEZa2Gis?feature=oembed" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen="true"></iframe>
 So chances are good that the floor of that skate park is magnetized. I do not believe it needs to be a fixed track, if it were a planer surface it probably works and allows for movement in any direction.
